9709/12

Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 359, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 212, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 380, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 729, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 84, 809, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 368, 920, 403]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve with equation \(y = a\sin (bx) + c\) for \(0\leqslant x\leqslant 2\pi\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are positive constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 414, 144, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 414, 386, 433]]<|/det|>
State the values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 414, 918, 433]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 725, 141, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 725, 920, 760]]<|/det|>
For these values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\), determine the number of solutions in the interval \(0 \leqslant x \leqslant 2\pi\) for each of the following equations:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 771, 180, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 771, 358, 789]]<|/det|>
\(a\sin (bx) + c = 7 - x\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 771, 917, 789]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 863, 180, 880]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 863, 398, 880]]<|/det|>
\(a\sin (bx) + c = 2\pi (x - 1).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 863, 917, 880]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 759, 92]]<|/det|>
The first term of an arithmetic progression is \(-20\) and the common difference is 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 569, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the sum of the first 20 terms of the progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 352, 761, 371]]<|/det|>
It is given that the sum of the first \(2k\) terms is 10 times the sum of the first \(k\) terms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 383, 146, 402]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 383, 311, 402]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 383, 920, 402]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 71, 688, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of each of the following:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 144, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 112, 232, 141]]<|/det|>
\[\left(x + \frac{3}{x^{2}}\right)^{6}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 116, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 185, 395]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 375, 306, 405]]<|/det|>
\[(4x^{3} - 5)\left(x + \frac{3}{x^{2}}\right)^{6}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 92, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 73, 544, 102]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = \frac{2x + 1}{2x - 1}\) for \(x < \frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 125, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 125, 180, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 125, 390, 144]]<|/det|>
State the value of \(\operatorname {f}(-1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 280, 180, 298]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 295, 779, 606]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 625, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = \operatorname {f}(x)\). Sketch the graph of \(y = \operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\) on this diagram. Show any relevant mirror line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 641, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[143, 673, 180, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 672, 747, 692]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\) and state the domain of the function \(\operatorname {f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 673, 920, 692]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 544, 447]]<|/det|>
The function g is defined by \(\mathrm{g}(x) = 3x + 2\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 458, 146, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 415, 477]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x) = \mathrm{gf}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 81, 680, 327]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 344, 920, 395]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a metal plate \(OABCDEF\) consisting of sectors of two circles, each with centre \(O\). The radii of sectors \(AOB\) and \(EOF\) are \(r \text{cm}\) and the radius of sector \(COD\) is \(2r \text{cm}\). Angle \(AOB =\) angle \(EOF = \theta\) radians and angle \(COD = 2\theta\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 405, 774, 426]]<|/det|>
It is given that the perimeter of the plate is \(14\mathrm{cm}\) and the area of the plate is \(10\mathrm{cm}^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 435, 548, 457]]<|/det|>
Given that \(r > \frac{3}{2}\) and \(\theta < \frac{3}{4}\), find the values of \(r\) and \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 437, 917, 456]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 75, 751, 95]]<|/det|>
The equation of a circle is \(x^{2} + y^{2} + px + 2y + q = 0\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 920, 145]]<|/det|>
Express the equation in the form \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\), where \(a\) is to be given in terms of \(p\) and \(r^2\) is to be given in terms of \(p\) and \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 123, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 757, 395]]<|/det|>
The line with equation \(x + 2y = 10\) is the tangent to the circle at the point \(A(4, 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 403, 146, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 403, 180, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 401, 653, 421]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the normal to the circle at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 402, 920, 421]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 435, 917, 453]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 333, 143, 351]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 633, 351]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the line and the curve do **not** intersect.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 435, 383]]<|/det|>
Find the set of possible values of \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 638, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given that the equation \(\mathrm{f}^{\prime}(x) = 0\) can be expressed in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[421, 102, 616, 122]]<|/det|>
\[125x^{2} - 128x + 192 = 0.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 136, 144, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Determine, making your reasoning clear, whether f is an increasing function, a decreasing function or neither.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
